Toggle Buttons

A toggle button is a specialized control which has two states: on or off.

Coming soon.

What they're for...

Toggles are typically used for filtering the display of items in an interface, or for turning functions on or off.

Use when...

Implementation

Toggle buttons, like simple buttons, result in an immediate action, but the result toggles between two states. Clicking/pressing the button shows the action selected, signifying that it is active. Clicking/pressing the button again returns it to its previous state, signifying that it is inactive. Toggle buttons with more than two states also exist, but we do not have an IBM-wide standard for their use.

The two states are represented by a single button with two halves, or by a single button with an icon to indicate whether the state is 'on' or 'off'.

If the text describing the toggle states is long, then use a toggle slider, and put the text for the states as a label for the slider.

Multiple-state 'toggles' are actually radio buttons or check boxes that have been grouped together and given a button-like display for easier use. These elements can be grouped, and can either behave independently (see Check boxes), or work as part of a group to represent an exclusive choice within the set (see Radio buttons).

Single toggle

Add 'data-toggle="button"' for single state toggle buttons.

                          <button class="btn btn-primary" type="button" data-toggle="button">
                       Single Toggle</button>

Grouped toggle buttons

Toggle buttons can be grouped, and can either behave independently like checkboxes, or work as part of a group to represent an exclusive choice within the set, like radio buttons.

Check box toggle

Add 'data-toggle="buttons-checkbox"' for checkbox style toggling on btn-group.

This function is not yet implemented.

Radio button toggle

Add 'data-toggle="buttons-radio"' for radio style toggling on btn-group.

Styling for this function has not yet been incorporated.

                                <div class="btn-group data-toggle="buttons-radio">

                                    <label class="btn btn-default">

                                        <input type="radio" name="options" id="option1"> 1 day

                                    </label>

                                    <label class="btn btn-default">

                                        <input type="radio" name="options" id="option2"> 30 days

                                    </label>

                                    <label class="btn btn-default">

                                        <input type="radio" name="options" id="option3"> 60 days

                                    </label>

                                    <label class="btn btn-default">

                                        <input type="radio" name="options" id="option4"> 90 days

                                    </label>

                                </div>

States

The following states are available in both mobile and non-mobile environments:

Enabled
A button that a user can act on.
Disabled
A button that a user can not act on.
Selected
A button is selected when the user presses and holds the mouse button down - or pushes and holds if the user is using a mobile device
Hover
A button is in a hover state when the mouse or user's finger moves over it. This state is not available on all mobile OS platforms and devices.

These states apply to non-mobile devices:

Default
A default button is the one that initially has focus, and will be activated when the user presses the Enter key or the Space bar key. There is no distinct visual to identify the default.
Focus
A button other than the default button gains focus when the user navigates to it using the keyboard - desktop only

Each state has their own visual treatments. Multiple states are supported â€” for example, a button that is enabled (active) will additionally show a hover state when the mouse moves over it, while a disabled button will not.

Accessibility

See the Button pattern for detailed accessibility guidelines.

Globalization

Button text must be isolated for translation and allow sufficient expansion space. The position of the buttons must not be fixed. See Globalization Design Guideline A4.
